meanings.definition: To divide or cause to divide into two sharply contrasting groups or sets of opinions or beliefs.
meanings.sent1: The controversial topic of the new law will polarise the community.
meanings.sent2: The political issue has the potential to polarise the voters.
meanings.sent3: The debate over pizza toppings managed to polarise the entire party.
meanings.sent4: Her strong stance on the matter seemed to polarise even the most neutral observers.
meanings.sent5: The intense discussion on climate change served to polarise the audience further.

meanings.definition: To cause something to acquire polarity.
meanings.sent1: The magnet was able to polarise the metal filings.
meanings.sent2: The electric charge helped to polarise the atoms in the material.
meanings.sent3: The experiment accidentally polarised the entire lab equipment.
meanings.sent4: The strong magnetic field was able to polarise the compass needle.
meanings.sent5: The special lens was designed to polarise the light for better visibility.
